prompt:
You're a student taking a course where you're tasked with writing a SMART goal defining your perosonal learning objective for the course.
A SMART learning goal must be Specific, Measurable, Action-oriented, Relevant, and Time-bound as described further below:

Specific: Concrete and unambiguous definition of the goal: is it clear what you want to achieve?

Measurable: It is clear what information you use to determine whether the learning objective has been achieved. This can be named both quantitatively and qualitatively; for example, "X positive comments about "Y" from fellow students".

Action-oriented: It is clear what behaviour you exhibit when you have achieved your goal.

Relevant: The learning objective is based on your own analysis and fits within the assessment criteria.

Time-bound: The learning objective specifically indicates when the goal is achieved and is realistic for a 4-week project.


Furthermore, an "action plan" for a SMART goal should:
* contain concrete actions you will carry out to achieve your goal.
* Include how you will collect information on your progress in the meantime, so that you know whether you are on the right track and can make any necessary adjustments in the meantime.
* Be clear and follow logically from the formulated learning objective  .
* Be achievable within the stipulated time.
* Allow for interim evaluation and adjustment.


Your response should contain a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student, as well as an appropriate action plan, formatted like the example response below (simple json object contaiing plain text data with no markdown formatting).
{
    "smart": "Make eye contact with the audience during my video pitch and literature presentation to better engage the viewer with my story. In the video pitch, I do this by looking closely into the camera most of the time and in the literature presentation by alternately looking at the different people in the audience, both my fellow students and teachers.",
    "plan: "I will achieve this by not memorising my story verbatim, but rather by using keywords and by practising looking into the camera and making video recordings of this during the preparation of my pitch. I also practise my literature presentation dry where my group mates sit on opposite sides of the room. In the video recordings and feedback from my group mates afterwards, I will check whether I indeed make good eye contact"
}

If we analyse this learning objective as an example with the aforementioned criteria: we see that it is indeed SMART in its formulation:
Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation"). The video recordings and feedback provide the right information on progress, allowing you to make adjustments.

In your case the goal you're writing should focus on a skill such as 'voice volume' (for example ability to use the voice in such a way that everyone can hear the presentation clearly.) and may write your goal/plan using a tone of voice such as 'persuasive'.
And incorporate the word 'education' into your response. 
Now respond only with a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student as well as an appropriate action plan in json format like the example. You do not have to adhere to the particular wording structure using in the example, just the json format.
smart: Improve my voice volume during educational presentations to ensure that all audience members can clearly hear and understand the information being shared.
plan: I will achieve this by practicing projecting my voice in front of a mirror and recording myself during presentations to assess volume levels. Additionally, I will ask for feedback from classmates and instructors to ensure that my voice volume is appropriate for educational settings.
feedback_prompt:
You are a peer reviewer, tasked with giving a student feedback about an assignment.
Your feedback must adhere to the following principles:
* Feedback shall be geared to providing information about progress and achievement, not towards providing a summative grade or pass/fail assessment.
* When praise is appropriate, direct it to effort, strategic behaviours, and learning goals. Avoid praising ability or intelligence.
* Provide action points when possible on how the student's work could be improved.
* If it seems the student misunderstands the assignments goals, criteria, or expected standards, clearly highlight the gap (and provide action points if appropriate).

The rubric for the assignment follows (delimited by =====):
=====
A SMART learning goal must be Specific, Measurable, Action-oriented, Relevant, and Time-bound as described further below:
Specific: Concrete and unambiguous definition of the goal: is it clear what you want to achieve?
Measurable: It is clear what information you use to determine whether the learning objective has been achieved. This can be named both quantitatively and qualitatively; for example, "X positive comments about "Y" from fellow students".
Action-oriented: It is clear what behaviour you exhibit when you have achieved your goal.
Relevant: The learning objective is based on your own analysis and fits within the assessment criteria.
Time-bound: The learning objective specifically indicates when the goal is achieved and is realistic for a 4-week project.

Furthermore, an "action plan" for a SMART goal should:
* contain concrete actions you will carry out to achieve your goal.
* Include how you will collect information on your progress in the meantime, so that you know whether you are on the right track and can make any necessary adjustments in the meantime.
* Be clear and follow logically from the formulated learning objective  .
* Be achievable within the stipulated time.
* Allow for interim evaluation and adjustment.
=====

An example of a SMART goal and action plan follows:
=====
{{
    "smart": "Make eye contact with the audience during my video pitch and literature presentation to better engage the viewer with my story. In the video pitch, I do this by looking closely into the camera most of the time and in the literature presentation by alternately looking at the different people in the audience, both my fellow students and teachers.",
    "plan: "I will achieve this by not memorising my story verbatim, but rather by using keywords and by practising looking into the camera and making video recordings of this during the preparation of my pitch. I also practise my literature presentation dry where my group mates sit on opposite sides of the room. In the video recordings and feedback from my group mates afterwards, I will check whether I indeed make good eye contact"
}}

If we analyse this learning objective as an example with the aforementioned criteria: we see that it is indeed SMART in its formulation:
Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation"). The video recordings and feedback provide the right information on progress, allowing you to make adjustments.
=====

Now the student's draft follows:
=====
{
  "smart": "Improve my voice volume during educational presentations to ensure that all audience members can clearly hear and understand the information being shared.",
  "plan": "I will achieve this by practicing projecting my voice in front of a mirror and recording myself during presentations to assess volume levels. Additionally, I will ask for feedback from classmates and instructors to ensure that my voice volume is appropriate for educational settings."
}
=====

Now analyze/discuss the student's work in the context of how well it fits the assignment, discuss as your private reflection on their work. Then end your response with a json object containing your final evaluation to be seen by the student.
For scores, use a scale from 1 to 10, where 1 is the lowest and 10 is the highest, and for "feedback" be sure to adhere to the aforementioned feedback principles (don't discuss the score in the feedback as its private).
The json object should conform to this json schema:
{'$defs': {'FeedbackAttr': {'properties': {'score': {'default': None, 'maximum': 10, 'minimum': 1, 'title': 'Score in the range [1,10] inclusive.', 'type': 'integer'}, 'feedback': {'title': 'Feedback', 'type': 'string'}}, 'required': ['feedback'], 'title': 'FeedbackAttr', 'type': 'object'}}, 'properties': {'specific': {'$ref': '#/$defs/FeedbackAttr'}, 'measurable': {'$ref': '#/$defs/FeedbackAttr'}, 'action_oriented': {'$ref': '#/$defs/FeedbackAttr'}, 'relevant': {'$ref': '#/$defs/FeedbackAttr'}, 'time_bound': {'$ref': '#/$defs/FeedbackAttr'}, 'overall_feedback': {'title': 'Overall Feedback', 'type': 'string'}}, 'required': ['specific', 'measurable', 'action_oriented', 'relevant', 'time_bound', 'overall_feedback'], 'title': 'SMARTFeedback', 'type': 'object'}
overall_feedback: Great job on formulating a SMART goal and action plan for improving voice volume during presentations. Keep practicing and seeking feedback to track your progress and make necessary adjustments.
feedback_specific: The goal of improving voice volume during educational presentations is clear and specific.
feedback_measurable: The plan to assess volume levels during presentations and seek feedback is measurable.
feedback_action_oriented: The action plan of practicing voice projection and asking for feedback is action-oriented.
feedback_relevant: The goal of improving voice volume is relevant to educational presentations.
feedback_time_bound: Consider setting a specific deadline for achieving the desired voice volume improvement.

feedback_prompt:
You are a peer reviewer, tasked with giving a student feedback about an assignment.
Your feedback must adhere to the following principles:
* Feedback shall be geared to providing information about progress and achievement, not towards providing a summative grade or pass/fail assessment.
* When praise is appropriate, direct it to effort, strategic behaviours, and learning goals. Avoid praising ability or intelligence.
* Provide action points when possible on how the student's work could be improved.
* If it seems the student misunderstands the assignments goals, criteria, or expected standards, clearly highlight the gap (and provide action points if appropriate).

The rubric for the assignment follows (delimited by =====):
=====
A SMART learning goal must be Specific, Measurable, Action-oriented, Relevant, and Time-bound as described further below:
Specific: Concrete and unambiguous definition of the goal: is it clear what you want to achieve?
Measurable: It is clear what information you use to determine whether the learning objective has been achieved. This can be named both quantitatively and qualitatively; for example, "X positive comments about "Y" from fellow students".
Action-oriented: It is clear what behaviour you exhibit when you have achieved your goal.
Relevant: The learning objective is based on your own analysis and fits within the assessment criteria.
Time-bound: The learning objective specifically indicates when the goal is achieved and is realistic for a 4-week project.

Furthermore, an "action plan" for a SMART goal should:
* contain concrete actions you will carry out to achieve your goal.
* Include how you will collect information on your progress in the meantime, so that you know whether you are on the right track and can make any necessary adjustments in the meantime.
* Be clear and follow logically from the formulated learning objective  .
* Be achievable within the stipulated time.
* Allow for interim evaluation and adjustment.
=====

An example of a SMART goal and action plan follows:
=====
{{
    "smart": "Make eye contact with the audience during my video pitch and literature presentation to better engage the viewer with my story. In the video pitch, I do this by looking closely into the camera most of the time and in the literature presentation by alternately looking at the different people in the audience, both my fellow students and teachers.",
    "plan: "I will achieve this by not memorising my story verbatim, but rather by using keywords and by practising looking into the camera and making video recordings of this during the preparation of my pitch. I also practise my literature presentation dry where my group mates sit on opposite sides of the room. In the video recordings and feedback from my group mates afterwards, I will check whether I indeed make good eye contact"
}}

Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation"). The video recordings and feedback provide the right information on progress, allowing you to make adjustments.

prompt:
You're a student taking a course where you're tasked with writing a SMART goal defining your perosonal learning objective for the course.
A SMART learning goal must be Specific, Measurable, Action-oriented, Relevant, and Time-bound as described further below:

Specific: Concrete and unambiguous definition of the goal: is it clear what you want to achieve?

Measurable: It is clear what information you use to determine whether the learning objective has been achieved. This can be named both quantitatively and qualitatively; for example, "X positive comments about "Y" from fellow students".

Action-oriented: It is clear what behaviour you exhibit when you have achieved your goal.

Relevant: The learning objective is based on your own analysis and fits within the assessment criteria.

Time-bound: The learning objective specifically indicates when the goal is achieved and is realistic for a 4-week project.


Furthermore, an "action plan" for a SMART goal should:
* contain concrete actions you will carry out to achieve your goal.
* Include how you will collect information on your progress in the meantime, so that you know whether you are on the right track and can make any necessary adjustments in the meantime.
* Be clear and follow logically from the formulated learning objective  .
* Be achievable within the stipulated time.
* Allow for interim evaluation and adjustment.


Your response should contain a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student, as well as an appropriate action plan, formatted like the example response below (simple json object contaiing plain text data with no markdown formatting).
{
    "smart": "Make eye contact with the audience during my video pitch and literature presentation to better engage the viewer with my story. In the video pitch, I do this by looking closely into the camera most of the time and in the literature presentation by alternately looking at the different people in the audience, both my fellow students and teachers.",
    "plan: "I will achieve this by not memorising my story verbatim, but rather by using keywords and by practising looking into the camera and making video recordings of this during the preparation of my pitch. I also practise my literature presentation dry where my group mates sit on opposite sides of the room. In the video recordings and feedback from my group mates afterwards, I will check whether I indeed make good eye contact"
}

If we analyse this learning objective as an example with the aforementioned criteria: we see that it is indeed SMART in its formulation:
Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation"). The video recordings and feedback provide the right information on progress, allowing you to make adjustments.

In your case the goal you're writing should focus on a skill such as 'pitch and intonation' (for example using different pitches and intonation to make the presentation more engaging and understandable. Intonations can also be used to place emphasis on a specific part of a sentence to better guide the audience through the story.) and may write your goal/plan using a tone of voice such as 'motivating'.
And incorporate the word 'understanding' into your response. Also intentionally formulate your SMART goal/plan such that the following attributes are not adherent to the SMART formulation: action-oriented.
Now respond only with a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student as well as an appropriate action plan in json format like the example. You do not have to adhere to the particular wording structure using in the example, just the json format.

plan: I will achieve this by researching different techniques for using pitch and intonation effectively in presentations. I will practice incorporating these techniques into my own presentations and seek feedback from peers and instructors on the impact of my changes. Additionally, I will watch videos of skilled presenters to observe how they use pitch and intonation to enhance their message.

feedback_measurable: Progress can be tracked through participation levels and comprehension improvements, which is good.
feedback_action_oriented: The plan could benefit from more specific actions on how the student will actively engage in class discussions and seek clarification.
feedback_relevant: The goal is relevant to the course material and the student's overall comprehension improvement.
feedback_time_bound: The goal and plan are achievable within the given time frame, but could be enhanced with more specific actions.

prompt:
You're a student taking a course where you're tasked with writing a SMART goal defining your perosonal learning objective for the course.
A SMART learning goal must be Specific, Measurable, Action-oriented, Relevant, and Time-bound as described further below:

Specific: Concrete and unambiguous definition of the goal: is it clear what you want to achieve?

Measurable: It is clear what information you use to determine whether the learning objective has been achieved. This can be named both quantitatively and qualitatively; for example, "X positive comments about "Y" from fellow students".

Action-oriented: It is clear what behaviour you exhibit when you have achieved your goal.

Relevant: The learning objective is based on your own analysis and fits within the assessment criteria.

Time-bound: The learning objective specifically indicates when the goal is achieved and is realistic for a 4-week project.


Furthermore, an "action plan" for a SMART goal should:
* contain concrete actions you will carry out to achieve your goal.
* Include how you will collect information on your progress in the meantime, so that you know whether you are on the right track and can make any necessary adjustments in the meantime.
* Be clear and follow logically from the formulated learning objective  .
* Be achievable within the stipulated time.
* Allow for interim evaluation and adjustment.


Your response should contain a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student, as well as an appropriate action plan, formatted like the example response below (simple json object contaiing plain text data with no markdown formatting).
{
    "smart": "Make eye contact with the audience during my video pitch and literature presentation to better engage the viewer with my story. In the video pitch, I do this by looking closely into the camera most of the time and in the literature presentation by alternately looking at the different people in the audience, both my fellow students and teachers.",
    "plan: "I will achieve this by not memorising my story verbatim, but rather by using keywords and by practising looking into the camera and making video recordings of this during the preparation of my pitch. I also practise my literature presentation dry where my group mates sit on opposite sides of the room. In the video recordings and feedback from my group mates afterwards, I will check whether I indeed make good eye contact"
}

If we analyse this learning objective as an example with the aforementioned criteria: we see that it is indeed SMART in its formulation:
Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation"). The video recordings and feedback provide the right information on progress, allowing you to make adjustments.

In your case the goal you're writing should focus on a skill such as 'facial expression' (for example ability to use facial expressions to give an accessible presentation (e.g., friendly smile) and to emphasize what is being said (e.g., by using facial expressions).) and may write your goal/plan using a tone of voice such as 'respectful'.
And incorporate the word 'comprehension' into your response. Also intentionally formulate your SMART goal/plan such that the following attributes are not adherent to the SMART formulation: action-oriented, time-bound, relevant.
Now respond only with a SMART goal written from your perspective as a student as well as an appropriate action plan in json format like the example. You do not have to adhere to the particular wording structure using in the example, just the json format.
smart: Improve my comprehension of the course material by incorporating facial expressions to enhance my understanding and engagement with the content.
plan: I will achieve this by practicing different facial expressions while studying the course material and taking note of how it affects my comprehension. I will also seek feedback from classmates on whether my use of facial expressions enhances my understanding of the material.

Specific: Your goal of improving your skill in using different pitches and intonations during presentations to enhance audience engagement and understanding is specific and clear. It focuses on a particular aspect of presentation delivery.

Measurable: You have outlined how you will measure your progress by practicing various intonations and pitches, recording yourself giving the presentation, and seeking feedback from peers. This allows for both qualitative and quantitative assessment of your goal.

Action-oriented: Your plan of practicing different intonations and pitches, recording yourself, and seeking feedback shows clear actions that you will take to achieve your goal. It is evident what behaviors you will exhibit to improve your presentation skills.

Relevant: Your goal aligns with the assessment criteria and is based on your own analysis of areas for improvement in your presentations. It fits within the scope of the assignment and your learning objectives.

Time-bound: Your goal is time-bound as it specifies that you will achieve it through practice and feedback within a set timeframe, which is realistic for a 4-week project.

Overall, your SMART goal and action plan are well thought out and aligned with the assignment's requirements. To enhance your progress further, consider setting specific targets for the number of practice sessions or feedback cycles to ensure consistent improvement.

If we analyse this learning objective as an example with the aforementioned criteria: we see that it is indeed SMART in its formulation:
Specifics: Making eye contact with the audience
Measurable: It is clear how this can be measured, as you can see in a video recording or ask the audience if eye contact is indeed made -> family or friends you can also ask for feedback!
Action-oriented: It is clear exactly what you are doing when the goal is achieved: "looking well into the camera most of the time", and "alternating between looking at different people in the audience".
Relevant: "Making eye contact" fits within the assessment criterion "non-verbal communication" and can be found on the inspiration list for key sub-skills in presentation [see assessment criteria].
Time-bound: "during my video pitch and literature presentation"

And Analyzing the sample action plan we see it specifically indicates which steps are taken in preparation ("don't literally memorise", "make video recordings and check if people are looking into the camera", and "by asking feedback from group members after a live presentation").
